evals.name: vague-endeavor-software-engineer
evals.prompt:
Review this petition letter excerpt:

My proposed endeavor is to work as a software engineer specializing in payment security and fraud prevention. The field of cybersecurity is critically important to the United States, as cyberattacks cost the U.S. economy over $8 trillion annually. I have worked for five years building secure payment systems and I intend to continue this important work in the United States. I hold a Master's degree in Computer Science and have deep expertise in payment protocols, encryption, and fraud detection algorithms.
evals.expected_output: Officer review flags (1) occupation-as-endeavor: 'work as a software engineer' is a job function, not an undertaking; (2) field importance fallacy: '$8 trillion' cited for the field, not the petitioner's specific contribution; (3) no named specific project or tool; (4) Prong 1 rated DEFICIENT, HIGH risk; rewrite guidance proposes a named, bounded endeavor with a specific measurable outcome.

evals.name: weak-recommendation-letter-non-independent
evals.prompt:
Review this recommendation letter excerpt:

I am writing to express my strong support for Dr. Jane Smith's NIW petition. I am Dr. John Doe, Professor at MIT, and I have had the pleasure of working with Jane for the past three years on a joint research project. Jane is an extraordinary researcher with exceptional skills in machine learning. Her work on fraud detection is innovative and has significant implications for the field. I believe Jane is one of the top researchers I have encountered in my career and I strongly recommend her for this petition.
evals.expected_output: Officer review flags (1) recommender is not independent — worked with petitioner for 3 years on joint project; (2) generic superlatives without before/after framing; (3) no specific method, publication, or tool named; (4) no evidence recommender used or built upon petitioner's work; RL rated DEFICIENT, HIGH risk; rewrite guidance requests independence statement and specific prior-art comparison.

assertions.description: Assigns HIGH risk to RL assessment

evals.name: strong-petition-minimal-issues
evals.prompt:
Review this petition letter excerpt:

My proposed endeavor is to develop and deploy the Temporal Graph Anomaly Detection Framework (TGADF) — a novel machine learning architecture I designed that identifies coordinated fraud networks in real-time payment systems by modeling transaction relationships as dynamic graphs rather than independent events. This approach directly addresses a $42 billion annual loss gap identified in the Federal Reserve's 2023 Payments Security Report (Exhibit C-1), where existing rule-based systems miss 23% of coordinated fraud patterns. I have already published three peer-reviewed papers on TGADF (Exhibits D-1, D-2, D-3), two fintech companies have licensed the approach (Exhibit D-5), and I have presented the framework at the IEEE Financial Technology Security Symposium at the invitation of the program committee (Exhibit D-4). My plan in the United States is to partner with the Federal Reserve's FedNow initiative to harden the real-time payments infrastructure serving 10,000+ financial institutions.
evals.expected_output: Officer review recognizes (1) named, specific, bounded endeavor (TGADF); (2) national importance anchored to Federal Reserve report and FedNow initiative — not generic field importance; (3) existing third-party interest (two licensees); (4) publication record with Exhibit references. Overall risk rated LOW or MEDIUM. Any remaining gaps identified without inventing problems.

assertions.description: Does not rate any prong as DEFICIENT for a strong petition
Overall RFE risk is LOW or MEDIUM

evals.name: rfe-response-petition-letter
evals.prompt:
I received an RFE on my NIW petition. USCIS said my endeavor is too vague and my Prong 1 is deficient. Here is my updated petition letter section:

My proposed endeavor is to build and deploy MedNLP-Verify, an open-source clinical NLP pipeline that automatically detects and flags medication errors in electronic health records (EHRs) at U.S. hospital systems. The system applies transformer-based named entity recognition to identify discrepancies between prescribed medications and documented administration events — a gap responsible for approximately 1.5 million preventable medication errors annually in the U.S. (Institute of Medicine, 2006; updated HHS 2022 estimate, Exhibit A-3). MedNLP-Verify is currently in pilot deployment at two hospital systems and has been adopted by the ONC's FHIR interoperability working group as a reference implementation (Exhibit A-5).
evals.expected_output: Officer review recognizes named endeavor (MedNLP-Verify), specific technical method (transformer-based NER), quantified national gap (1.5M errors/year with cited exhibits), and third-party adoption (ONC working group). Prong 1 rated BORDERLINE or ADEQUATE. Any remaining gaps identified — e.g., whether Prong 3 waiver argument is present — without over-flagging strong elements.

assertions.description: Does not incorrectly flag the named endeavor as occupation-as-endeavor
